tossups.question: A software package for modelling these structures uses strip algebra. The tip-growth model and the base-growth model describe one method of synthesizing arrays of these structures. A floating ferrocene/xylene catalyst can be used to synthesize these structures, whose metallic and semiconducting types can be distinguished by the lineshape of their G-minus Raman band. The bandgap of these structures is plotted on the y-axis of a Kataura plot. Depending on their (*) chiral angle, achiral examples of these molecules can have a zigzag or armchair configuration. These molecules can be single or multi-walled, and their single-walled varieties are essentially rolled-up graphene. For 10 points, name this form of fullerene in which carbon forms a cylindrical structure.
tossups.answer: carbon nanotubes [prompt on fullerene; do not accept or prompt or “buckminsterfullerene” or “buckyball”]

tossups.question: In one story, a man asks if God made this character, to which Ham Sandwich responds “Not all at one time, I reckon.” In another work, this character attempts to help a young boy find a parrot which recites random German numbers. One short story about this character was published in a literally tiny book for a dollhouse - that story ends with this character telling another “it’s a very superficial trick, and no doubt you will soon acquire it.” This character is fooled by Fetlock Jones in a “double-barrelled” Mark Twain story and appears in Michael Chabon’s The (*) Final Solution, where he appears as an old man keeping bees. That work’s title references “The Final Problem,” where this man dies at the Reichenbach Falls, though he was revived by popular demand. For 10 points, name this oft-pastiched detective created by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, who lives at 221B Baker Street.

Michal rebuked her husband for dancing in celebration of this object’s return, and she was therefore cursed to be barren until death. In 2009, Patriarch Abune Paulos said that he would unveil this object but then reneged on his promise the next day. The Philistines were cursed with a plague of either hemorrhoids or tumors when they held this item captive, so they returned it to the Israelistes. The Kebra Nagast narrates how (*) Menelik I transported this object. This item was created either by Bezalel and Oholiab or by Moses. This object was carried seven times around the walls of Jericho and was consulted with during multiple military campaigns. Records stopped mentioning this item after the Babylonian invasion of Jerusalem and the destruction of Solomon’s Temple. For 10 points, name this vessel that contains the tablets on which the ten commandments were inscribed.

Hardesty Maratta’s color theory influenced an artist based in this city who painted a sepia toned painting titled Cumulus Clouds. The credo “art for life’s sake” was advanced by a group that often exhibited their work at the Macbeth Gallery in this city. A quote about “girls hitching up their skirts” gave a group of artists from this city its name and was published in The Masses, for which they often painted covers. Walter Pach, Walt Kuhn, and (*) Arthur B. Davies staged an exhibition beginning in this city. The Philadelphia-born Robert Henri led a group of artists based in this city that grew out of a group known as The Eight. An exhibition beginning in this city was the site of ridicule of Duchamp’s (“dyoo-SHAWM’s”) Nude Descending a Staircase No. 2. For 10 points, the Armory Show was first staged in what city, which was depicted in the urban realist paintings of the Ashcan school?

Anderson and Anderson posited a thermal classification of these entities based on the derivative of temperature with respect to depth. The strain rate of these entities is equal to A times tau to the third power according to Glen’s flow law. Daily observations of the area-altitude distribution of these entities are fed to the PTAA model of mass balance in these entities. Structures created by these objects have a characteristic overdeepened profile. These objects can be divided into areas of (*) accumulation and ablation. These objects can create paternoster lakes. These structures use both abrasion and plucking to create characteristic U-shaped valleys. The till deposited as the result of these entities can create moraines. For 10 points, name these large masses of ice.

Two legends attribute the founding of this city either to Hercules upon saving the ninth ship of Jason’s fleet or to Hamilcar. King James I ordered Nachmanides to burn his ‘blasphemous’ pamphlet after a 1263 disputation in this city. Labor unionists protesting a military reservist call-up in this European city clashed with police and soldiers in 1909 during the Tragic Week. The anarchist union confederation CNT was founded in this city, which it lost to allied government troops in the May Days during a (*) civil war. After its country boycotted the 1936 Olympics in Nazi Berlin, this city planned to host a People’s Olympiad using the infrastructure of its 1929 International Exposition. The leader of the regional Generalitat was shot in this city’s Montjuïc (“mon-joo-eek”) Castle on the orders of Francisco Franco. For 10 points, name this capital of Catalonia in Spain.

This author experienced an “absolutely Homeric retching" during a hospital stay which he escaped by jumping out the fire escape in a hospital gown. This author included maps of Leopold Bloom's Dublin and sketches of the beetle Gregor Samsa in his collected "Lectures on Literature." He created a character who loses his luggage with his papers, which may be the wrong ones, while giving a guest lecture, and is insulted by the book's narrator V. V. This author of (*) Pnin (“pa-NEEN”) worked his interest in chess into his character Luzhin in The Defense. This lepidopterist described his synesthesia in his autobiography Speak, Memory, and created a professor who wrote a 999-line poem beginning "I was the shadow of the waxwing slain." That poem by John Shade is annotated by the allegedly Zemblan professor Charles Kinbote. For 10 points, name this author of Pale Fire.

A symphony inspired by this country ends with a coda which Otto Klemperer thought was so incongruous that he wrote a replacement for it. In a concertante (“con-cher-tan-te”) piece inspired by this country, the soloist plays a series of triple and quadruple-stops accompanied by the harp at the beginning of the last movement, which has the unusual tempo marking allegro guerrierro. The rhythm of an accented sixteenth note followed by an unaccented dotted eighth is sometimes called this country’s (*) “snap.” Folk tunes from this country such as “The Dusty Miller” and “Hey, Tuttie Tatie” were arranged as a fantasy for violin and orchestra by Max Bruch. It is not Italy, but a trip here inspired Felix Mendelssohn’s Symphony No. 3 as well as his Hebrides Overture. For 10 points, name this country home to the song “Auld Lang Syne.”
tossups.answer: Scotland [prompt on United Kingdom or UK; prompt on Great Britain]

tossups.question: The image of monks quibbling over how many angels fit on the head of a pin became a trope after this event. The memoirs of Olivier de la Marche describe the Feast of the Pheasant organized to promote a response to this event by Duke Philip the Good, whose composer Guillame Dufay wrote a motet lamenting it. One legend recounts that during this event the “Marble King” was turned to stone by an angel and hidden in a cave. The engineer Urban designed “The Basilic,” a (*) cannon dragged by sixty oxen, for use in this event. One side used greased logs during this event to transport its fleet overland, circumventing a chain barrier and entering the Golden Horn. Constantine XI was killed during this event, after which Mehmet II declared himself “Kayser-i-Rum.” For 10 points, name this Ottoman siege that toppled the Byantine Empire.
tossups.answer: Fall of Constantinople [or the Fall of Byzantium before mentioned; or the conquest of Istanbul; prompt on Fall of Eastern Rome or Fall of the Byzantine Empire]

tossups.question: An essay in The Oxford Handbook of Max Weber about this group's "late modernization" notes that unlike similar groups, Weber has "no fully developed sociology of [this group]." Richard Hofstadter's "The Paranoid Style in American Politics" stated that "anti-[this group] has always been the pornography of" a related group. Auguste Comte developed a positivist take on this group labelled "[this group] plus science," a reference to Comte's youthful (*) rejection of this group. Émile Durkheim wrote that this group possessed a normal level of integration, as opposed to the low levels of one counterpart and high levels among Jews. The book Suicide observed a lower suicide rate amongst, for 10 points, what religious group that is allegedly more community-centric than Protestants?
tossups.answer: Roman Catholics [or Roman Catholicism; or the Roman Catholic Church; prompt on Christians before "Protestant" is mentioned]

tossups.question: A character in this film awkwardly pretends to hide a “Sharpshooter of the Week” award that he received for getting five bullseyes in a day. Another character in this film temporarily lies about liking bananas in order to cover up an attempt to practice oral sex, and had earlier used the caption “just woke up like this… ugh” for a selfie despite having just put on makeup. Following an anxiety attack, this film’s protagonist works up the courage to sing karaoke at Kennedy Graves’s pool party. The word (*) “Gucci” is used to conclude motivational videos recorded by an Elsie Fisher-played character throughout this film, the last of which is buried in a time capsule that is meant to be opened four years later. For 10 points, name this movie, the 2018 directorial debut of Bo Burnham, which depicts Kayla’s last week of classes before she graduates from her final year of middle school.

The enanthate derivative of this compound has a longer half-life than its normal form. The Vermeulen and Sodegard methods are used to measure its concentration, and flutamide is used to blockade its receptor. It’s not aldosterone, but spironolactone blocks the effect of this compound to treat adult acne. High levels of DHEAS and this hormone suggest a tumor, rather than PCOS, in a patient with virilization. Finasteride prevents the conversion of this compound to its more potent (*) dihydro form by inhibiting 5-alpha reductase, and 17-beta-HSD transforms it to androstenedione (“an-drow-STEE-nuh-dee-own”). A protein that binds to this compound is synthesized by Sertoli cells. This hormone is secreted by Leydig cells in the testes. For 10 points, name this hormone that produces male secondary sex characteristics.

In the third book of A Treatise of Human Nature, David Hume argues that this concept arises from a “moral” relation, and that it cannot be understood “without fully comprehending the nature of justice.” In The Philosophy of Right, Hegel locates the rationale for this concept “not in the satisfaction of needs, but in the supersession of the pure subjectivity of personality.” An essay on this concept argues against both its origination in (*) labor and its status as a natural right, and uses the argument that “what is just must be useful, what is useful must be true,” and “what is true must be possible” to prove the impossibility of this concept. Another essay marks the origin of this concept in the idea of “mixing” one’s labor; that is Locke’s First Treatise on Government. For 10 points, identify this concept described as “theft” in a famous essay by Pierre Proudhon, whose title asks “What is,” this concept.

This leader defended a major domestic policy by asking, “Did Christianity fail because the world is not all Christian?” This leader quelled a rebellion at the Colito barracks that saw the capture of his foreign minister Oscar Kambona. This leader’s first vice president, Abeid Karume, had previously assumed the presidency of an island nation after John Okello overthrew (*) Sultan Jamshid bin Abdullah. In response to the annexation of the Kagera Salient, this leader invaded a northern neighbor, allowing Milton Obote to become president of Uganda. This leader’s policy of agricultural collectivization was known as “villagization” and was inspired by the principle of ujamaa, which he outlined in his Arusha Declaration. For 10 points, name this proponent of African socialism who oversaw the merger of Tanganyika with Zanzibar and became the first president of Tanzania.

In one work by this author, a character refuses to do a seduction scene because she has a friend in the audience whose husband just left her. That woman ends a play by this author by describing a couple “confident as the first day they began” and tells the audience that seven actors got food poisoning. Another character created by this author describes a star “straining away...to make something of itself” before saying “Good night.” In one play by this author, a woman wins a beauty pageant at the Ancient and Honorable Order of (*) Mammals. This playwright created the fourth-wall-breaking maid Lily Sabina, who narrates George’s invention of the wheel as the New Jersey Antrobus family survives an ice age, as well as a Stage Manager who narrates life in Grover’s Corners. For 10 points, name this playwright of The Skin of Our Teeth and Our Town.

A Mamluk artifact created through this art form unusually features the signature Mohammed ibn al-Zain six times and is erroneously named for St. Louis. An 8th century piece in this art form is simply signed “Sulayman” and is a ewer (“YOO-ur”) depicting a bird. It’s not embroidery, but chasing and repoussé are techniques in this art form, which is called filigree when it depicts intricate patterns. This art form can be decorated via cloisonné (“KLWA-zo-nay”), as in the “purse-lid” of (*) Sutton Hoo. The Croeseids were produced through this art form from a substance called electrum. The Lydians are thought to be the first to use this art form to produce currency which took the form of obols or drachma. For 10 points, name this art form which involves the hammering of alloys into shapes.
tossups.answer: metalwork [or metallurgy; accept any answer involving metals or alloys; accept more specific answers such as coinage; accept brass before “purse-lid”]

tossups.question: The only women serving at the national level of this organization, Leonora Barry, worked to integrate women into it, while the Great Chicago Fire prompted Mother Jones to join. The Louisiana Sugar Planters’ Association recruited whites to kill black laborers striking under the umbrella of this organization in Thibodeaux (“ti-buh-doh”). This organization lobbied heavily for the Chinese Exclusion Act and its members murdered Chinese miners in the (*) Rock Springs Massacre. This organization which recorded its secret rituals in the Adelphon Kruptos removed the words “Noble Order” from its name to mollify Catholics. Uriah Stephens founded this organization before being replaced by Terrence Powderly. For 10 points, name this early labor union blamed for the Haymarket Square Riot, resulting in its supporters joining the American Federation of Labor.
tossups.answer: Noble and Holy Order of the Knights of Labor [or K of L]

tossups.question: One of this author's titles relies on an original-language pun between words for "glory" and "drag" which a translator thought would mislead homosexuals to buy the book. Ingmar Bergman staged this man’s all-female play Madame de Sade, which spurred this author to write and star in his all-male play My Friend Hitler. In a work by this author, a boy is embarrassed by a man who drenches himself in a water fountain. That novel ends with a gang of boys drugging that man’s tea to dissect him. In that book, a man turns towards the sound of a (*) boat’s horn after having sex with Fusako, while being spied on through a peephole by Noboru. Another character by this author repeats "If you meet the Buddha in the road, kill him" before burning down a building. For 10 points, name this author of The Temple of the Golden Pavilion and The Sailor Who Fell From Grace with the Sea.

One of these objects impregnated a virgin who gave birth to an emerald which turned into the human Goranchacha; that object, whose son built a temple to worship him in Sugamuxi, is the deity Su’e in Muisca myth. A temple dedicated to one of these objects lies across from two other temples dedicated to Crosses in Palenque. Pedro de Alverado was confused with one of these objects who is commonly depicted fighting (*) Tlahuizcalpantecuhtli (“tla-WEEZ-cal-pan-te-KOO-tlee”). A toad-like monster named Tlaltecuhtli was depicted as eating one of these objects every night. Tonatiuh (“to-NAH-tee-oo”) eventually became one of these objects after Tecciztecatl (“tek-seez-TE-ca-tl”) refused to sacrifice himself, prompting Nanahuatzin to throw himself into a fire. Humans became fish after the earth was flooded by one of these objects which Chalchiutlicue (“chal-CHOO-tlee-kway”) became after Tlaloc served as the previous one. The Aztecs believed in five of, for 10 points, what celestial object?

The “gamma driver” and “minimal strain” are two conditions used to decompose this quantity into a lapse function and shift vectors within the ADM formalism. At most, the second derivatives of this quantity have 20 degrees of freedom independent of the coordinates. A vector field satisfies Killing’s equation if the Lie derivative of this quantity with respect to that vector field is zero. A connection is “compatible” with this quantity if the covariant derivative of this quantity is zero for that connection. A value of negative-one-half times the (*) Ricci curvature scalar times this quantity appears on the left-hand side of the Einstein field equations. This quantity can be written as the diagonal matrix “negative one, one, one, one” in the limit of Minkowski spacetime. For 10 points, name this tensor quantity which defines distance in general relativity, symbolized lower-case g.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about unusual home run trots in baseball history, for 10 points each.
answers_sanitized: San Francisco Giants AND St. Louis Cardinals [accept San Francisco AND St. Louis; or SFG AND STL]
parts: Edwin Encarnacion’s custom of rounding the bases with one arm raised has been dubbed “walking the [this bird]” by his teammates. As you may expect, the mascot of the MLB team from Pittsburgh is one of these birds.

During the contentious 1987 NLCS between these two teams, Jeffrey Leonard enraged pitcher Bob Forsch with his “one-flap down” routine, in which he’d trot slowly with one arm hanging at his side. Travis Ishikawa hit a series-winning, walk-off home run in a 2014 postseason series between these two teams.

Adam Rosales’s habit of sprinting around the bases after his home runs has made him the owner of nearly all the fastest home run trots measured by this technology for collecting baseball data, which was introduced in 2015.

bonuses.leadin: This kind of media was parodied in a highly saturated advertisement created by Lynda Benglis for Artforum that features her wearing a pair of sunglasses. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: pin-ups [accept pornorgaphy; prompt on magazine covers]
parts: Name this kind of media that takes up most of Eduardo Paolozzi’s Pop art collage I was a Rich Man’s Plaything, in which it appears above the image of an airplane next to the words “Keep ‘em flying!”
This Dutch-born abstract expressionist drew on a variety of sources from Paleolithic art like the Venus of Willendorf to pin-ups as the inspiration for his painting Woman I.
This artist critiqued the stereotypical depiction of women in B movies with her black and white series Untitled Film Stills, whose 21st entry shows a ‘City Girl’ with skyscrapers in the background.

bonuses.leadin: Groups with lone pairs of electrons tend to be ortho/para-directing for this reaction. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: electrophilic aromatic substitution [prompt on partial answer; accept EAS; anti-prompt on Friedel-Crafts]
parts: Name this class of reactions that is catalyzed by a Lewis acid in which an atom on a ring is replaced. A reaction of this type can be used to synthesize bromobenzene from benzene using ferric bromide as a catalyst.

In nucleophilic aromatic substitution, when the addition-elimination mechanism is not possible due to unusually low temperatures, the mechanism proceeds via one of these highly unstable intermediates. This intermediate is an example of a highly strained alkyne.

The strain of benzyne is attributed to poor overlap between two of these kinds of orbitals. This type of hybridization is seen in the central atom of trigonal planar molecules and in carbons in a double bond.

bonuses.leadin: A 1989 paper by Stewart Candlish complained that this philosopher’s work was routinely misunderstood, owing mostly to the stereotypes propagated by Bertrand Russell and G.E. Moore. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this British philosopher who attempted to give a description of “the Absolute” in his magnum opus, Appearance and Reality.

Bradley argued that relations could not be real because either they could not relate qualities to each other or require other relations to relate them to qualities, leading to this kind of situation. The “third man” in Plato’s Parmenides and Aquinas’ “first cause” are arguments that depend on this kind of situation.
This other philosophical work, written by A.J. Ayer, mocks Appearance and Reality in its section titled “The Elimination of Metaphysics.”

bonuses.leadin: One character in this play insists that she has not been able to taste food for ten years, while another makes fun of a man’s “savory swordfish succotash stories.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: The Last of the Red-Hot Lovers
parts: Name this play in which the fish-restaurant owner Barney Cashman tries and fails to seduce three women in his mother’s apartment.

The author of The Last of the Red-Hot Lovers created this character, who left a note on a pillow saying “We’re all out of Corn Flakes. F. U.” and makes linguini, not spaghetti, which is thrown onto his messy friend’s wall.
The Last of the Red-Hot Lovers is by this New York comedic playwright who created Felix Ungar and Oscar Madison in The Odd Couple.

bonuses.leadin: Sarah Cone Bryant wrote an early 20th-century pickaninny children’s book named for [this man] and His Auntie about a little black boy who keeps messing up errands. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this soldier who saved the life of Pelopidas at the Siege of Mantinea. This man introduced the oblique order of battle by stacking his left flank fifty ranks deep in a battle against Cleombrotus I.
That battle at Leuctra ended the hegemony of this city, which razed the Long Walls and installed the Thirty Tyrants after defeating Athens in the Peloponnesian War.
Epaminondas belonged to this city, which ruled the Boeotian league and won hegemony over most of Greece until its defeat to Philip II of Macedon at Chaeronea.

bonuses.leadin: The goddess Al-Lat is depicted with one of these specific images in Ayn esh-Shallāleh, while the Minaean god Wadd was depicted with one of them and a small disk of Venus. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify these objects which one ruler saw rise from the chest of a man whose daughter he wanted to marry in a dream.
That aforementioned ruler was the highly mythologized Osman I, the founder of this Turkish empire. His dream may have inspired the crescent and star found on the flag of this empire.

While the Quran stresses that the crescent moon is not Allah, the term Allah may have referred to an older pre-Islamic moon deity according to critics like Robert Morey. Muslims have also tried to disassociate Allah from this god, whose idol at the Ka’aba was used for divination with the aid of arrows.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist has a vision of Johanna Von Haller, who has this profession, as an archaic woman leading the title figure in Robertson Davies’ The Manticore. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: The Confessions of Zeno [or Zeno's Conscience, or La Coscienza di Zeno]
parts: Name this profession. One member of this profession named Spielvogel hears about “The Monkey” and ends a novel by saying “So. Now vee may perhaps to begin. Yes?”
In Portnoy’s Complaint, a book by this author, the protagonist monologues about his masturbation with a piece of liver to the psychiatrist Dr. Spielvogel. This author also wrote Goodbye, Columbus.

This Italo Svevo work is framed as a diary published by the title character’s psychiatrist as revenge for quitting his therapy. In it, the protagonist constantly vows to smoke his “last cigarette” and is slapped by his dying father.

bonuses.leadin: Texas Instruments' 7400 chip series uses this logic family to make logic gates, flip-flops, and more. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this logic family of devices that use BJTs and not FETs for both logic and amplifying functions.
This lead of a bipolar transistor is the input, controlling what current flows from the collector to the emitter. Its equivalent in FET transistors is the gate.

When the gate is off, a bipolar junction transistor effectively has two of these things back to back. These circuit elements only allow current to flow one way, and they can emit light if made of a direct-bandgap material.

bonuses.leadin: These people partner with ethnic Chinese in the practice of “Ali Baba” to obtain government-sponsored affirmative action contracts. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Bumiputra [or Bumiputera; anti-prompt on Orang Asli with “can you be less specific?”; prompt on BUT DO NOT REVEAL Malays or Malaysians]
parts: Give this term for the ethnically-native population who fought with immigrant Chinese during the 13 May incident. The New Economic Policy sought to redistribute wealth with preferential policies for this impoverished racial group.
The 13 May incident forced the resignation of Tunku Abdul Rahman, the first Prime Minister of this nation. This nation’s definition of Bumiputra includes natives of Sabah and Sarawak.

Race riots between Bumiputra Malays and Chinese in 1964 in this city led to its expulsion from the federation. This city-state’s People’s Action Party led by Lee Kuan Yew opposed Malaysian race-based affirmative action.

bonuses.leadin: One method of solving these equations relies on finding an integrating factor. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these equations which include variables and their derivatives. Ordinary ones contain one independent variable, whereas partial ones can have many independent variables.
This kind of linear ODE lacks a constant term; in other words every nonzero term of the equation depends only on the solution and its derivatives.

This principle, named for a French mathematician, allows one to solve an inhomogeneous partial differential equation from the corresponding initial value problem. For equations without spatial dependence, it reduces to variation of parameters.

bonuses.leadin: The third Sorrowful Mystery of the Rosary is titled for this object. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this object which is introduced alongside a scarlet robe in the Book of Matthew. It was housed in the Sainte-Chapelle after Baldwin II gave it to Louis IX.
Jesus was struck on the head after being given the crown of thorns and was derisively given the title King of these people, who included the Sanhedrin and priests who insisted on his crucifixion.

Later during the crucifixion, people mistakenly think Jesus is calling out this man when he asks why God has forsaken him. During the Transfiguration, Jesus says this man “truly shall first come”, referencing a prophecy from Malachi about his return.

bonuses.leadin: Mel Weinberg and Evelyn Knight made a plea deal to assist in this operation, for which they created the fictional Abdul Enterprises. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this sting operation in which fake Arab sheikhs offered bribes to U.S. congressmen in exchange for Atlantic City building permits and private immigration bills.
This federal law enforcement agency long run by J. Edgar Hoover carried out the ethically-dubious Abscam operation.

This journalist called Senator Larry Pressler a ‘hero’ for rebuffing the “sheikhs” and reporting them to the FBI. This longtime CBS anchor known as “the most trusted man in America” famously broke the news of the Kennedy assassination and ended broadcasts with the line “and that’s the way it is.”

bonuses.leadin: One novel by this author is set in motion by the murder of Colonel Sonriente at the hands of the Zany. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Mulata de tal [or A Kind of Mulatto]
parts: Name this author who created Miguel Angel Face, who dies imprisoned in cell 17 after being falsely told that his wife Camila had become a mistress of “the President.”
Asturias’ novel El Señor Presidente typifies a genre of Latin American novels about people with this occupation. Augusto Bastos’ I, the Supreme is about Dr. Francia, one of these people.

Asturias’s final major work was this novel that begins with Yumi selling his wife Catalina to the corn-husk devil Tazol. After the two are reunited in this novel, they study sorcery to battle the titular woman.

bonuses.leadin: Though not finalized until decades later, this composer’s Lachian Dances were mostly written when he was collecting folk songs in the 1890s. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this composer whose interest in folk song may have influenced the vocal styles of an opera by him in which the title character is accused of murdering her baby on the day of her wedding to Laca.
This English composer collected folk songs such as “Bushes and Briars” and composed the English Folk Song Suite for military band. He also wrote Fantasia on ‘Greensleeves’ and A Sea Symphony.
This composer published Seven Spanish Folksongs for piano and soprano in 1914, and incorporated Spanish folk music and dance styles into his ballet score for The Three-Cornered Hat.

bonuses.leadin: The “Historian’s Quarrel” divided scholars in this country over the interpretation of its national crimes. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: A. J. P. (Alan John Percival) Taylor
parts: Name this country which is the subject of the Sonderweg theory, which states that partial modernization led it through a “special path” from militaristic monarchy to the Third Reich and finally to democracy.

The Sonderweg theory was championed by Hans-Ulrich Wehler, who belonged to this historiographical school named for a German city. This school draws on modernization theory to interpret social history.

This early British proponent of the Sonderweg interpretation claimed Nazism traced all the way back to Germanic tribes in The Course of German History. This fierce rival of Hugh Trevor-Roper introduced a revisionist interpretation of the conflict in his Origins of the Second World War.

bonuses.leadin: Eric Klinenberg studied the results of a heat wave that hit this city and found that people who were more socially isolated were more likely to die. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: symbolic interactionism [prompt on interactionism or interactionist]
parts: Name this most populous city in Illinois, the namesake of an influential school of sociology.
One concept to come out of the Chicago school was this two-word phrase, the understanding a person has of how people in their group perceive them and what is expected of them in daily life.
George Herbert Mead introduced the generalized other as well as this theoretical approach to sociology, which views society as the product of interactions between individuals.

bonuses.leadin: In one short story by this author, Janet visits her dying father in the hospital and tells him about her trip to the planetarium. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Canadian author of “The Moons of Jupiter.” Her collection Lives of Girls and Women recounts the story of Del Jordan coming of age in the small Ontario town of Jubilee.
In this story by Munro, a girl with Down syndrome performs the title Gluck work beautifully, to the surprise of those attending Miss Marsalles’ piano recital.
Nita copes with her husband’s recent death and fabricates a story to a man who killed his own family in this other Munro short story.

bonuses.leadin: Strawberries are in fact not berries and instead fall under this category of fruits. For 10 points each,
parts: Name this category of fruits, including raspberries and strawberries, that arise from multiple carpels in a single flower.

Strawberries are also accessory fruits, meaning their flesh is NOT derived from this flower structure. Pollen travels through the style to reach this organ where fertilization occurs. The ovule is found within this organ.

Strawberries’ seedlike surface structures are in fact achenes (“AY-keens”), a dry fruit that, like grains, do NOT undergo this process. Other fruits like milkweed pods undergo this process, in which they rupture to release seeds.

bonuses.leadin: Give these Italian operatic terms, for 10 points each:
parts: This movement, exemplified by Mascagni’s Cavalleria rusticana and Leoncavallo’s Pagliacci, emphasized portraying life as it is, often with lower-class characters.
This term, which comes from the Italian for “weaving,” refers to the range of a piece where the majority of the singer’s notes lie or where the singer is most comfortable.
Carlo Broschi, also known as Farinielli, was among the most celebrated of these male singers, whose testes were cut off before puberty to preserve their high voices.
